title: Suicide?
content:
If I had the elixir of life, (A substance that can make anyone live forever, so long as they keep drinking it.) and I refused to take it, thus condemming myself to eventual, preventable death, would I be commiting suicide? After all, I'd be fully aware that by doing what I was I'd definitely die in future.

I hope this bit of philisophic empty-headedness amuses you.

title: Re: Suicide?
content:
Stopping artificially lengthening life isn't the same as commiting suicide, so no.
Although of course anno 2007 we live quite a bit longer than we used to, which you could call artificial.
Once an animal becomes self aware and all that, a whole bunch of pretty much black and white rules tend to stop applying in the the nice and simple way they used to.
Humans evolved in a natural way, so the process is nature doing its work.
Humans also screw up the planet (or "change" the planet, to sound less negative) much more than any other animal has, which I'd call artificial.
I suppose the fact that nature created a product doesn't mean what the product does is still part of nature.

If I see someone drown and don't attempt to save him/her, am I killing that person?
What if I try and fail; is it my fault the person died?
What if I removed the railing that is supposed to keep people from walling in the water a week before, and while unknowingly trying to lean against the no-longer-there railing, the person got in the situation he is in now, him drowning.
Is it my fault?
If I drink a few too many beers, walk right on the edge, and fall in and drown myself, does my lack of common sense equal suicide?
Some of these are more gray, but my vote stays "No".Retodon8

title: Suicide
content:
Why call suicide a crime if there's nobody to punish (or remove from society, or whatever), that's just useless.

Although of course I don't exactly have warm, fuzzy feelings for those people that decide it's a good idea to jump in front of a train, quite possibly disabling others to stop functioning (in society, or whatever) properly.
I recently read those kinds of decisions are usually made last minute, meaning they haven't been thought through propely, so "you can't really blame them" was the gist of the article.
It was supposedly info from people who know about these things, but aren't you supposed to have enough common sense to consider the repercussions, for others, just by not being brain dead throughout your life and having thought about "stuff"?
Oh well!

Suicide is a word that has its meaning based on some other words, "life" and "death", words that don't have a real meaning, or lots of different ones, whichever you prefer, so by definition there isn't a right answer to the original question, if you ask me.
If there is in fact a right answer, it is one that changes over time.
